question_text:
A vegetarian restaurant wants to know people's eating habits
\( 50 \) people in Town \( A \) are asked if they eat meat. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town A } \\
\hline Do you eat meat? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 39 \) \\
\hline No & \( 11 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} \( 200 \) people in Town B are asked if they eat meat. \begin{tabular}{|cc|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town B } \\
\hline Do you eat meat? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 143 \) \\
\hline No & \( 57 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which results are more reliable?
construct: Compare relative frequencies in order to determine which prediction is likely to be more reliable
subject: Experimental Probability and Relative Frequency
incorrect_text:
276    Town A
Name: AnswerText, dtype: object
misconception_desc: Does not know that sample size affects reliability

There are also 10 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to the other rectangle). 
Pattern 3 is made up of 3 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. question_text:
Here is the graph of
\(
y=\frac{4}{x}
\)

What is the value of \( y \) when \( x=-1 \) ? ![A graph with two curves. Y axis from -5 to 5 and x axis from -5 to 5 marked in increments of 1.  One curve is in the positive x, positive y quadrant. It starts at the top close to the line x = 1, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the x axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the line y =1. It goes through (1, 4) (2,2) and (4,1).  One curve is in the negative x negative y quadrant. It starts at the top left of the quadrant almost parallel to y = -1, then we move right and it curves downwards towards the y axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the x = -1 line. It goes through (-4, -1) (-2, -2) and (-1,-4)]()
construct: Given an x value, find the corresponding y value from a non-linear graph
subject: Cubics and Reciprocals
misconception_desc: Believes dividing a positive by a negative gives a positive answer

question_text: Which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 40^{\degree} \) and \( 50^{\degree} \) either side?
construct: Construct a triangle using Angle-Side-Angle
subject: Construct Triangle
correct_text:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the other end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle

question_text:
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\)
construct: Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable
subject: Simultaneous Equations
incorrect_text:
6312    Add Pair \( 1 \)\r\nSubtract Pair \( 2 \)
Name: AnswerText, dtype: object
misconception_desc: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we do the operation matching the sign (+ if positive, - if negative)

question_text:
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
 \frac{3 x}{2} + 1 =5 
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{3 x}{2}=4 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 3 x+1=10 \)

Who is correct?
construct: Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers
subject: Linear Equations
incorrect_text:
6925    Only Katie
Name: AnswerText, dtype: object
misconception_desc: Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount

question_text:

question_text: This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 2.7+35.9 \). The second bubble says "I then added the decimal part 0.3 + 0.5 = 0.8". The third bubble says "I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8. So 12.3 + 4.5 = 16.8".]()

How many more Year \( 7 s \) than Year 8s study Chinese? ![An image of a bar chart with bars striped red and white for French, blue for Spanish and white for Chinese. The x-axis is marked 'year group' with options 7-11, and the y-axis is marked 'number of children'. ]()

subject: Block Graphs and Bar Charts
misconception_desc: Finds total instead of difference when asked 'How many more'

question_text:

Katie says they are perpendicular
Who do you agree with? ![Two blue lines, each with a small red line marked across them about halfway up. The two blue lines do not touch, but they are closer together at one end.]()

subject: Parallel Lines
misconception_desc: Thinks that if two lines do not intersect on a diagram then they will never intersect and are therefore parallel

question_text:

\( (t) \).

Which of the following does that \( 0.8 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with s on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 2/3 of the way up the graph, 1/5 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/5 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()

misconception_desc: Believes the gradient of a speed-time graph is the speed

question_text: The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is ![Triangle with base labelled b and perpendicular height labelled h]() \( A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h) \) Rearrange this to make the base, \( b \), the subject.
construct: Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed
subject: Rearranging Formula and Equations
incorrect_text:
7412    \( b=\frac{1}{2}(h \times A) \)
Name: AnswerText, dtype: object
misconception_desc: Believes they can change the subject of a formula just by swapping two letters

question_text: The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is ![Triangle with base labelled b and perpendicular height labelled h]() \( A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h) \) Rearrange this to make the base, \( b \), the subject.

question_text:

Who is correct?

question_text:
Jo and Paul are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Jo says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) anticlockwise"

Paul says: "a rotation of \( +270^{\degree} \) about \( (-1,1)^{\prime \prime} \)

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two trapeziums drawn on it and a centre of rotation marked on, one space to the right and one space up from the origin. Trapezium P has the coordinates: (-4,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-4,1). Trapezium Q has the coordinates: (-4,-2) (-4,0) (-3,0) and (-1,-2).]()
construct: Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object
subject: Rotation
misconception_desc: Forgets to give the centre of rotation
